title: Seattle Showed up for May Day Just Can't Get Enough?
content: Photos by Brittne Lunniss Yesterday, a coalition of unions, immigrant rights groups, and other anti-Trump protestors took over the streets on Capitol Hill. The rally brought together more than 1,000 protesters at Cal Anderson Park, and then, with the assistance of car escorts and bike blockades, they marched to the federal building, stretching across blocks at a time. And it wasn't the only protest in the region. At the same time, 200 lawyers were ceremonially retaking their oath at the King County Superior Court, and immigrant advocates were marching on the Northwest Detention Center in Tacoma. There are May Day protests in every major city every year, but this year, they drew from the same kind of energyâ€”even on a Thursdayâ€”that the Hands Off! protests harnessed in April. Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators protested across the country. This is the kind of progressive coalition building we need. Earlier this month, Stranger columnist Kendall Turner asked social scientists if we know what makes a successful protest movement. She wrote that â€œwe know that over the last century, almost no protest movement that has mobilized 3.5 percent of a population has failed to achieve its goals.â€ Hands Off! didnâ€™t hit those numbersâ€”the highest estimates were 1 percent of the populationâ€”and neither did yesterdayâ€™s, but gatherings like these are how we build the foundation to get to that 3.5 percent. â€œFew things stop a movementâ€™s momentum as quickly as not having something to do next,â€ wrote Turner. â€œNumbers matter, yes, but so does consistency in participation in a protest movement.â€ Stranger contributing photographer Brittne Lunniss captured it all, so if you werenâ€™t able to make it, hereâ€™s a little taste of the magic. And if you can, get down to Olympia tomorrow for the All Labor March!

title: Wisconsin Judgeâ€™s Arrest Couldnâ€™t Have Happened in Washington Just Can't Get Enough?
content: Last Friday, the FBI arrested Milwaukee County Circuit Judge Hannah Dugan, claiming that she helped a migrant avoid arrest from federal immigration authorities. While highly irregular, according to law professionals, there is precedent for this arrestâ€”pretty much the same situation happened in 2019 during the first Trump administration. A Massachusetts judge ushered a defendant out of a courtroom where Immigrations and Customs Enforcement officers laid in wait, ready to do some arresting. That judge faced charges (though wasnâ€™t dragged out in handcuffs in the public, performative way Dugan was). President Joe Biden ultimately tossed out the charges in the 2019 case. Whether or not Dugan did what sheâ€™s accused of, thereâ€™s precedent for judges acting in this way. And, no, Attorney General Pam Bondi, this is not â€œradical leftist judgesâ€ standing in the way of Trumpâ€™s agenda. These behaviors are a reaction to ICEâ€™s continued presence in US courtrooms causing a chilling effect on the legal system and making it harder for courts to do their job. Washington, still a bastion of sanity in some arenas, tackled this ghoulish ICE behavior back in 2020 with a law banning courthouse arrests without warrants, and blocking staffâ€”including lawyers, judges, and security officersâ€”from tipping off ICE. Itâ€™s the kind of check on power that we used to rely on the legal system to provide. This started back in December 2019, when Mary E. Fairhurst, then the chief justice of the Washington Supreme Court, penned a letter to presiding judges around Washington about ICE presence at the courts. â€œThe problem of immigration arrests at or around our courthouses has deeply troubled me because of the effect it has on our immigrant populations and the growing perception that we are a cooperating entity in those arrests,â€ Fairhurst wrote. According to Christopher Sanders, a former federal public defender in Seattle, ICE is a constant presence at state courthouses. â€œClients would be arrested by ICE at their state courthouse hearings and then brought down the street and charged with immigration crime,â€ Sanders said. Sanders said these officers usually come into courtrooms and donâ€™t identify themselves. Theyâ€™re often in plain clothes. Fairhurstâ€™s letter continued: â€œI do oppose using our locations as the site for those arrests. Our courthouses should be treated as â€œsensitive locationsâ€ like schools and hospital, as a place where everyone should be free to come and go without fear. Our courthouse should not be used as a magnet for targeting certain populations, regardless of their legal status.â€ The outrage turned into House Bill 2567 during the 2019-2020 legislative session. The bill contained safeguards outlawing warrantless civil immigration arrests at state courthouses. Beyond that, the bill stopped courts from collecting information about immigration status unless relevant to a personâ€™s trial and prevented anyone sharing private personal information with ICEâ€”they couldnâ€™t even alert ICE about who would be in the courtroom. Additionally, under the bill, court security started collecting the names and purposes of all ICE officers who showed up on any particular day and they alerted judges ahead of proceedings about the officersâ€™ presence. Sanders and his wife, Erika Evans, who is now running for Seattle City Attorney, jumpstarted a letter writing campaign with the Minority and Justice Commission in support of HB 2567. Their letters advocated for the bill, but also addressed the question of whether a court could be truly impartial if it didnâ€™t willingly let the people within its walls be detained by ICEâ€”a question that is paramount in Duganâ€™s arrest. â€œWe do not believe that HB 2567 jeopardizes the independence of the judiciary,â€ the Minority and Justice Commission letter read. â€œRather, it recognizes the sanctity of courthouses, the rule of law, and the critical role that court personnel play in fostering public confidence in the judicial branch. Access to our courts is fundamental to a functioning democracy.â€ Unfortunately, our federal government seems far more interested in theatrics than in maintaining a functioning democracy. Judges who act in the interest of access and fairness, like Dugan may have, will instead face the wrath of Bondi. â€œI think some of these judges think they are beyond and above the law, and they are not,â€ Bondi told Fox News in an interview last week. â€œWe are sending a very strong message today: If you are harboring a fugitive, we donâ€™t care who you are. If you are helping hide one, if you are giving a [gang] member guns, anyone who is illegally in this country, we will come after you, and we will prosecute you. We will find you.â€

title: Aegis Fires Two Workers for Sharing Stranger Article, Union and Employees Say Just Can't Get Enough?
content: Imagine getting fired for sharing an article with your co-workers. Not porn, not political commentary, not raunchy jokes. A news article, just like this one. According to two employees at Aegis Living, it just happened in King County twice. Jason Bova-Havers says that on their day off on May 27th, a former co-worker sent him something to read: a story published last month in The Stranger titled, â€œWhatâ€™s Behind the Gilded Doors of Aegis Living?â€ The article contained allegations against the senior living chain Aegis Living from employees, former employees, and families of residents, ranging from shady business practices to illegal anti-union actions, discrimination, elder neglect, and more. Bova-Havers had worked for Aegis for the past five years, so naturally they were curious. They told The Stranger that they weren't all that surprised about what was reported in the article, but still felt like it was worth passing along. Maybe this is something my boss should see, they remember thinking, and dropped a link to the story in a group chat he had going with a co-worker and his immediate boss. Two days later, during their shift as a line cook at Aegis Living Shoreline, Bova-Havers was called into the General Managerâ€™s office, their bossâ€™ boss. â€œYouâ€™re going to want to sit down,â€ Bova-Havers says a Human Resources rep told them. â€œYou recently sent a text message to your coworkers that was seen as â€˜below board.â€™ So weâ€™re letting you go.â€ That was it. Will Hudson read that same article, also passed to him by a friend. It was about the company heâ€™d worked for the past two and a half years, first as care staff then recently as a member of the maintenance team at Aegis Living Madison. While he was at work the next day he printed the article off in the employee break room so his co-workers could read it, too. â€œI just wanted to inform them, see what their opinions and takes around it were,â€ Hudson says. Then he went back to work. â€œDidnâ€™t think nothing of it.â€ When Hudson came into work on June 9th, he was called into his bossâ€™s office and questioned. He says theyâ€™d interviewed a couple of his co-workers already before he was called in to his bossâ€™s office. â€œAre you the one who printed off this paper?â€ he says he was asked. â€œYes,â€ Hudson says he replied. â€œWe donâ€™t allow that here. We have to let you go,â€ he says he was told. Aegis did not respond to The Strangerâ€™s request for comment about the two fired workers. They also did not respond to repeated requests for comment over months of reporting for the original article, and in the month since publication has not issued any public statement refuting the articleâ€™s wide-ranging allegations. Since these firings, SEIU 775 has filed Unfair Labor Practice charges with the National Labor Relations Board against Aegis Living, alleging the company â€œunlawfully terminatedâ€ the two workers for â€œconcerted, protected activitiesâ€ covered by the National Labor Relations Act. The complaint states â€œdue to the egregious and hallmark nature of this violationâ€ the union is seeking injunctive relief that would allow these workers to be reinstated with back pay. Even though Bova-Havers and Hudson werenâ€™t members of the union, SEIU sees their firings as an attempt by Aegis to cool pro-union activity. â€œWe're going to push as hard as we can to get them to take action on these complaints,â€ says Adam Glickman, the Secretary Treasurer of SEIU 775. He sees this as a first-amendment fight, made even more important in the current political climate. â€œIt's just outrageous that in the middle of a workforce crisis where long-term care facilities are struggling to hire caregivers, particularly this company Aegis that pays less than most other employers, that they would fire workers for sharing newspaper articles,â€ Glickman says. â€œIt seems like a slap in the face to their residents that they care so little about their care that they would fire workers for such an absurd reason. They're so afraid, so anti-union, so afraid of their workers organizing, that they would endanger the care of their residents by firing people for sharing a news article. It's just shocking.â€ But no matter how it happened, Bova-Havers and Hudson are out of their jobs. Luckily, both Bova-Havers and Hudson have been able to find work since. Bova-Havers is happy at his new full-time job as a pastry chef, which was his original job at Aegis. â€œI do miss my crew in the kitchen,â€ he says. â€œI worry about them. I hope they get better pay and protections. Or, hell, just jobs that appreciate them.â€ Will has found some work dog sitting and dog walking, but heâ€™s still looking for something long-term. And heâ€™s still upset about what happened. â€œAfter being fired, I was devastated,â€ Will says. â€œThe residents thatâ€™d see me every day, now I donâ€™t get to see them anymore. All because Aegis doesnâ€™t want people to know the truth: that Aegis is corrupt.â€ Have a tip about Aegis Living? Reach out at editor@thestranger.com.

title: Current Weather Game Center Car crashes into University Place restaurant twice in failed towing attempt
content: Cloudy 62 75 57 Today 75 57 Sunday 72 57 Monday 73 58 Latest Weathercast Now 62 Sun 72 Mon 73 by KOMO News Staff TOPICS: SEATTLE â€” A bizarre series of events unfolded early on July 30 when a car crashed into the UP Pho and Teriyaki restaurant twice in quick succession, causing significant damage to the entrance. Deputies responded to the scene on July 30 around 6 a.m. to find the vehicle abandoned in the parking lot. According to surveillance footage, the maroon car had been parked at a nearby AutoZone since the previous day. The driver had informed employees that the vehicle was not functioning properly and that he would return to tow it. At approximately 3:45 a.m., a white Honda Pilot with a dolly attempted to tow the maroon car. The vehicle was initially pulled from its parking spot around 5:15 a.m., but the tow strap failed, leaving it at the far end of the parking lot. A second attempt to secure the vehicle around 5:50 a.m. resulted in the vehicle rolling down the lot and crashing into the restaurant. The Honda driver made a third attempt to tow the vehicle, but the strap broke again, causing the car to crash into the restaurant a second time. Ultimately, the driver and a female passenger abandoned the maroon car after it became stuck along a retention wall and curb. University Place Deputies are investigating the incident as a hit-and-run collision and are seeking assistance from the public. They urge anyone who recognizes the white Honda Pilot or the female passenger involved to come forward.

title: Current Weather Game Center Seattle Kraken hockey player, sea troll charged by grizzly bear during Alaska fishing trip
content: Mostly Cloudy 69 70 57 Today 70 57 Monday 74 58 Tuesday 71 61 Latest Weathercast Now 69 Mon 74 Tue 71 by KOMO News Staff TOPICS: ANCHORAGE, Alaska â€” The Seattle Kraken hockey team and their sea troll mascot Buoy had quite the heart-racing experience after a grizzly bear charged them during a fly fishing excursion. The Kraken were in Anchorage for their annual partnership trip with the Bristol Bay Native Corporation, a union that brings a blend of hockey and community engagement to hockey fans in Alaska. RELATED | Seattle Kraken in the news - matches, players, and more The week-long event included a hockey camp hosted by the Anchorage Hockey Academy. The camp featured Kraken forward John Hayden, the team's mascot Buoy, and various youth hockey coaches from the Kraken organization. However, during a fly fishing excursion on June 25 in Katmai National Park, an uninvited guest showed up - a grizzly bear. Video provided by Kraken shows the bear watching the fisherpeople from the other side of the shallow river. As its presence is flagged and everyone begins to quickly evacuate the water, the bear is seen advancing on them, rushing toward the group and sending spray flying before veering away again. It seemed particularly interested in the blue-haired Buouy, who, ever the good sport, never stopped smiling as he slogged away to safety. "I want to blame it on Buoy. They were pretty interested in his whole look. We got out of it okay, but it was a close call," Hayden said.
